title: Friday, 21st April, 2017

WS Atkins PLC (ATK:LSE): Last: 2,080, up 98 (+4.94%), High: 2,088, Low: 2,060, Volume: 2.07m

... turns out it was just formality. Old types in the UK tend to remember Marconi and suchlike and think suspensions are significant. In the US they're usually not.

BE11:16am

Anyway, the low level of irrevocables has revived some hopes of a counter.

11:17 am

BE11:18am

Here comes Peel Hunt.

BE11:18am

Recommended cash acquisition at 2,080p: The price of 2,080p represents a
premium of 35% to the closing price of 1,540p on 31 March 2017 (the last
business day before the announcement of the Possible Offer), 42% to the
volume-weighted average price of 1,468p for the three months ended 31 March
2017 and 44% to the volume-weighted average price of 1,449p for the 12
months ended 31 March 2017. There will be no final dividend for the financial
year ending 31 March 2017. The acquisition values Atkins’ equity at £2.1bn. It
is intended that the acquisition will be implemented by means of a Courtsanctioned scheme of arrangement under Part 26 of the Companies Act. The
acquisition, which is subject to regulatory approvals (as soon as reasonably
practical and before 31 July 2017) and requires Atkins’ shareholder approval
(within 28 days), is expected to complete in Q3 of 2017. SNC is financing the
consideration from the proceeds of a bought dealing offering, proceeds from a
private placement with CDPQ, a term loan with CDPQ and new and existing
credit facilities.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

The price of 2,080p represents 9.8x adjusted EBITDA for the trailing 12-month
period to 30 September 2016 post synergies (c£70m by the end of the first full
financial year, ie 2018 – c£52m from Atkins and c£17m from SNC) and
including the pension deficit. (Enterprise value based upon: EBITDA of
£181.7m, net debt of £10m and IAS19 pension deficit net of tax and other post
employment liabilities of £356.0m)
Valuation: The 2,080p price is equivalent to 16.9x Mar 2018E EPS and
12.1x Mar 2018E EBITDA. In aggregate, this represents a 17% premium to
the FTSE 250.

BE11:19am

The hope is pinned to just 0.14% of irrevocables from Atkins directors.

Reckitt Benckiser Group PLC (RB.:LSE): Last: 7,163, down 112 (-1.54%), High: 7,218, Low: 7,117, Volume: 624.11k
BE11:21am

One of the year-to-date's best performers, I noticed yesterday.

11:21 am
PM11:21am

Trading up-date here http://www.investe...1704210700079198C/

BE11:22am

Perhaps counterintuitively given most people are unconvinced by the Mead acquisition.

BE11:22am

Though I guess it's as much a dollar story as anything.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Story today is that sales ain't great.

BE11:23am

Slightly weaker than consensus.

BE11:23am

RBC can summarise.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

This is the first Q1 miss of the seven companies we cover that have reported this week. Not a disastrous miss (flat like-for-like sales growth versus company-compiled consensus expectations of +1%) with full year guidance maintained (like-for-like expected to be at least +3%), but nonetheless things don’t seem to be getting much easier for RB. Scholl/Amopé continues to pay the price of last year’s failed ‘Wet & Dry’ launch as the sell-in annualised in the quarter, while Airwick struggled in ENA ‘due to market challenges’. It’s true that the Healthcare comps get significantly easier from here on in, but a reversion to 2015’s 14% like-for-like growth seems a distant prospect.

Geographically, similar trends were evident as a number of other consumer business have reported: Russia and China performed well, while Brazil remains problematic. Finally, and unsurprisingly, RB has ‘commenced a strategic review of our Food business’. With the Mead Johnson acquisition expected to complete by the end of Q3, we retain our Underperform rating.

BE11:24am

As can Shore.

BE11:24am

Weak trading continues as Q1 misses expectations. Reckitt Benckiser has reported weak trading through the Q1 2017 period, with LFL sales flat against an already subdued expectation of +1% growth. Despite the disappointing performance, management states trading has been ‘in line with expectations’, and that the group remains on track for its full year net revenue target of +3% LFL growth. With very strong contribution from currency translation total sales increased by c15% to £2,645m (Shore forecast £,2624, consensus £2,643m).

The trading weakness has been most evident across the group’s developed markets, with North American LFL sales flat (Shore forecast +0.3%) and the ‘Rest of ENA’ LFL sales declining by -3% (Shore forecast -1%), the well documented headwinds in Scholl/Amope are the primary drivers for the weak performance, with a ‘strong’ performance in Mucinex and Durex reported.

The +4% LFL growth in Emerging markets (DvM) was in line with both Shore Capital (+3.9%) and market expectations (+4.3%), though continue to be held back by trading in South Korea due to the HS issues which we expect will be annualised as we approach the end of Q2 2017.

The weak trading is evident across all of RB’s categories, with only Hygiene positive at +3%. Health LFL sales are flat with Home and Portfolio down -4% and -6% respectively.

Whilst trading has been subdued, 2017 to date has been a very busy period for RB with the proposed acquisition of the of the Mead Johnson infant formula business announced (on track for completion in Q3 2017), and a strategic review of the Food business also underway. Food delivered another good period of trading through Q1, with LFL sales up 3%.

We see today’s update as disappointing for RB, though with headwinds set to annualise as we move through Q2 and into Q3 and with comparatives easing we do anticipate trading momentum to improve through the year, as such we do not anticipate changing forecasts looking for FY2017 EPS of 340.7p (consensus 337.9p) which does not include any contribution from Mead Johnson at this stage.

Trading on a FY2017 PER of 21.4x and an EV/EBITDA multiple of 16.0x, expected to yield 2.3% we reiterate our HOLD recommendation, though expect the stock to see some weakness today.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

I'll note again, as I did with Unilever yesterday ..... 21 times for soap looks odd to me.

BE11:25am

But it's your money.

Talktalk Telecom Group PLC (TALK:LSE): Last: 197.75, up 8.75 (+4.63%), High: 200.00, Low: 194.30, Volume: 1.53m
BE11:26am

Yep, it's just the HSBC upgrade.

11:26 am
PM11:26am

Top of the 250 all of a sudden on that

BE11:26am

Good note. Sector thing about BT getting its wings clipped .....

BE11:27am

..... and Ofcom accidentally snuffing out broadband investment, which is good for the resellers.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

In 2014’s Fixed Access Market Review, Ofcom reserved its right in future to cost-orientate the price of wholesale fibre, and with the WLA review (published 31 March) the regulator is now proposing to do just that. We think that such a step would be highly counter-productive, as it would not only impact BT’s ability and incentive to invest, but would also we believe render a substantial portion of Virgin Media’s intended build programme uneconomic. The present report analyses the impact of the WLA market review proposals on three of the market’s main protagonists, BT, Virgin Media and TalkTalk.

BE11:29am

BT – price controls undermine entire fibre revenue stream: On the day Ofcom released its Consultation, we estimated a negative FY21 cash flow impact on BT of more than GBP300m pa (see How to undermine the UK fibre investment case, 31 March 2017). Our new model now assumes a broader range of factors, including a far wider set of regulatory price adjustments, and we conclude that Ofcom’s central proposals would lead to a negative impact of GBP367m pa from FY21e or -9.4%. Our assessment of BT’s equity value falls by GBP5bn, or 50p/share.

PM11:29am

Blimey, I didn't realise there had been this effect

11:29 am
PM11:29am

To actually dampen investment

PM11:30am

By leaving future action uncertain

PM11:30am

Crazy

11:30 am
BE11:30am

It's a hypothesis rather than a fact, but yes, if HSBC is right then Ofcom seems to have made quite a large error of strategy.

BE11:30am

TalkTalk – an obvious beneficiary, upgrade to Buy: The WLA review proposes cuts to a pair of the company’s key input prices providing visibility on an improving cost base through to FY21, as well as a market that will focus on price competition rather than network investment. The company still needs to improve its underlying operating performance, but it is being given a huge boost by the regulator. An improved EBITDA margin drives our TP increase to 250p. With 30.9% upside, we upgrade to Buy.

BE11:31am

let me drag out some of the working .....

11:31 am
PM11:32am

Go on then

BE11:32am

Here's the relevant par of the Ofcom doc.

BE11:32am

“In broad terms the choice is between continuing the existing approach of pricing flexibility, which allows BT to set wholesale prices, subject to the need to ensure that its competitors have sufficient margin to compete at the retail level, and setting a cost-based price which our current analysis indicates would be below today’s wholesale prices. In the latter case, we would expect that much of the reduction in wholesale prices would be passed through to consumers in the form of lower retail prices.”

11:33 am
BE11:33am

In other words, Ofcom believes the impact of its proposals would be to suck cash out of the sector (to the tune, we estimate, of GBP367m per annum at BT alone. Yet, at the same time, it views its measures as “encouraging and enabling network investment.”

BE11:34am

That's HSBC.

PM11:34am

interesting

11:34 am
BE11:34am

One of the reasons Ofcom’s price controls are likely to have such a substantial impact on the sector’s

revenues is that the product it intends to price regulate, with bandwidth of 40Mbps, is (more than)

capable of servicing the needs of the vast majority of users both today and over the next several

years. Faster products should merely be seen as offering still higher bandwidth at a premium to the

price of the more-than-sufficient substitute of 40Mbps. While the higher bandwidth of these still faster

offerings can command a certain price premium to the 40Mbps product, if the price of the latter falls

by (say) GBP20 pa, then the price of those premium products will tend to fall by the same amount.

In other words, cutting the price of a 40Mbps offering undermines not only the revenues from this one

product, but also from all faster products from all operators (not just BT) as well. The economics here

are well understood, and formed a core component of the reasoning behind the EC’s original

decision in the non-discrimination and cost methodology recommendation in 2013 not to cut ULL

prices further (in the awareness it would undermine fibre pricing and so undermine investment).

BE11:34am

But that'll do on that theme.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Crispin Holder, director of finance, has also left the business according to MCA magazine. If there was an accounting, fraud or trading issue then the company would have had to update the market. The truth is probably more prosaic. The early fixes had been made and it is time for a new skill-set to move the business forward. RTN remains a credible long-term recovery story in our view and any share price weakness should be exploited by investors seeking to build positions.
Andy McCue joined after Nightingale and has considerably strengthened Restaurant Group's management bench over the last year with the appointments of Murray McGowan (ex Costa and KFC) as managing director, leisure division; Lucinda Woods (ex Paddy Power) as interim chief marketing officer; Debbie Moore (ex ISG and Spirit) as HR director and most recently Mike van Deventer (ex Wetherspoon) as group financial controller. Now that Nightingale has departed, Restaurant Group will take its time to trawl the market for a new finance director.

BE11:37am

(@Otter: that makes me sad.)

BE11:38am

And Liberum.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

We see the general upweighting of highly quality staff as a positive. The Board will now conduct a search for a permanent replacement and while there is more than adequate internal skill-set we would not be suprised if an interim role is potentially filled. Under the leadership of Debbie Hewitt the Board too has been improved over the past year with the addition of Graham Clemett (June 2016), Mike Tye (April 2016), who together bring a wealth of Plc and lesiure experience. We would see today's announcement as part of the journey to signficantly improve the quality of all key positions that will be a strong cultural fit for a data driven business moving forward. Any weakness in our view is a BUYing opportunity. The Company will next provide a trading update on 26 May 2017 when we would expect to hear news of how the initiatives have gone which could provide confidence in the direction that RTN is heading.

Restaurant Group PLC (RTN:LSE): Last: 355.35, down 10.05 (-2.75%), High: 362.40, Low: 346.20, Volume: 682.34k

PM11:43am

Here's the Investec stuff -- so we can dig it up in future

11:43 am
PM11:44am

And wave it back at Steve

PM11:44am

We update our model and valuation for the proposed US launch and recent £50m funding round. While detail is limited and subject to execution risk, we believe the new US initiative adds two new drivers to the Purplebricks investment case and possible valuation: 1) The sheer scale of the US market adds new optionality; and 2) Investors may now re-evaluate Purplebricks as a credible scalable international platform model with a higher valuation basis. Our DCF-based probability-weighted PT rises to 366p (185p before).

PM11:44am

Forecasts – UK and Australia unchanged. We assume a $55m US start-up loss, skewed to FY18/19E with breakeven in 2H20E. This implies a FY18E group EBITDA loss vs profit before, with profit in FY19E. We forecast EBITDA breakeven for the UK in FY17E (unchanged), Australia FY19E (unchanged), and US FY21E.
Cash comfort – post the gross £50m placing, FY17E net cash of £67m falls to a low of £50m at FY18E, suggesting balance sheet security and strategic options.
Valuation – we use DCF and probability-weighted scenario analysis to drive our new PT of 366p. Our base case analysis (WACC/TGR 15%/4%) suggests that the US adds 113p of incremental value, with our bull case pointing to 369p.
US market opportunity – US housing transactions (5.5m/year) are c. 4x the size of UK/Australia combined, with the agent commission market ($70bn) over 7x larger given high fees (5-6%) paid to both selling and buying agents. This looks ripe for disruption by the high quality, lower cost Purplebricks model.
US regional/state roll-out – as per the UK/Australia launches and to control risk, we expect PURP to roll out gradually state by state. California, the largest US state market, has total agency fees ($11.5bn) above the UK and Australia combined.
PURP US model – a highly experienced UK senior launch team will work with key US staff, e.g. the new US CEO Eric Eckardt (20 years’ experience in real estate, finance and tech). While we await detail, PURP should leverage its hybrid Local Property Expert (LPE) and tech platform model to provide a cheaper, more efficient/transparent service in the existing market. We assume an overall fee per transaction at $4k (1.5% average house value) vs market average c. $15k (5.3%)

11:44 am
PM11:44am

So yeah, Purplebricks to become the Google of real estate Omg smile

PM11:45am

Longandwrong -- they do!

undefined

Sports Direct International PLC (SPD:LSE): Last: 308.60, down 6.4 (-2.03%), High: 319.00, Low: 307.90, Volume: 435.06k

BE11:46am

PM11:48am

Apols for ignorance, but does Sports Direct have any existing business in the US?

BE11:48am

11:48 am
BE11:48am

PM11:49am

BE11:49am

11:49 am
BE11:49am

BE11:50am

Though it wasn't why shareholders bought Sports Direct. And neither, arguably, is this.

BE11:50am

Incidentally, here's what you get when you email Sports Direct external flack -- Keith "The" Bishop of Dean Street, Soho.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Thank you for contacting Sports Direct via KBA

Due to the high volume of correspondence that we receive each day we are unable to respond directly to each request.

If you do not receive a personal response within 48 hours we have been unable to help you at this time but thank you for contacting us.

BE11:50am

Which is nice.

BE11:50am

Oh, and the company's internal IR department's apparently on holiday this week.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

So that's nice too.

BE11:51am

Good to keep shareholders informed.

BE11:51am

Johnathan Prichard at Peel Hunt was a Sports Direct turnaround bull. But he has a tether, and he's very near the end of it.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Having just embarked on arguably the most audacious turnaround in the history of UK retailing (taking Sports Direct from “Pile it high, Sell it cheap” to the “Selfridges of Sport”), Mr Ashley has decided that this is not enough of a challenge and is taking on the USA as well. $101m is being spent on 50 lossmaking Delaware-based stores (fascias Bob’s and Eastern Mountain Sports) out of the Eastern Outfitters Chapter 11 process: they had $26m of losses last year so this is quite a decent downgrade. More crucial to us is what is says about management mindset. It should be in lockdown for years, focussing on its core business. Clearly this isn’t the case and we are rapidly losing patience with the company’s lack of ability to stick to a strategy, not to mention the complete investor relations’ vacuum. The
short-term change in underlying forecasts momentum is possible as the UK consumer stays above ground, and the shares discount plenty of bad news, but we are no more than stale bulls really.

BE11:52am

Bob’s and Eastern Mountain Sports – $26m of losses: We understand that, at the last count, there were about 90 Bob’s and EasternMountain Sports stores under the Eastern Outfitters umbrella, but that the deal announced today alludes to about 50, implying a price of $2m per store. They lost $26m last year, a not insignificant sum, and it is hard to argue why that number would get any lower this year or next, given that this is Sports Direct’s first foray into the US. Doing nothing other than look at Google images (there’s nothing resembling any background info available from SPD), the stores look sizeable (think a larger out of town Sports Direct for Bob’s, and a Go Outdoors style size for Eastern). They are based along the eastern seaboard we think.

BE11:52am

Eye-catching timing: There is no reason per se why Sports Direct shouldn’t go to the States one day: the US shopper likes a bargain as much as the next man, and long term, there will be parts of the market where Sports Direct can add value. However we find the timing extraordinary. At present, management’s strategy is to transform Sports Direct stores from their current discount nature
and turn the brand into the “Selfridges of Sport”, renowned for merchandising, service and exclusive product. This is as big a retail project as we can remember in terms of changing the way a company comes to market. To us, this should be all-encompassing, and should leave absolutely no management time for anything else. All cash should be channelled in this direction too. What is not required, in our view, is a major (and not inexpensive) distraction, 3000 miles away. We don’t really care if this proves to be an unmissable deal. The shares (and arguably the company at large) depend on the success of the UK transformation programme and it seems that this focus is not shared by the company.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Is anything really a surprise? Does this come as a shock? No. Does the fact that Investor Relations are on holiday until 27 April surprise us? No. UK momentum will turn sooner than the market thinks, but days like today don’t help the buy case, so we cool our jets. Add to 350p.

BE11:52am

Sorry! IR's on holiday next week as well!

BE11:52am

Awesome.

11:53 am
PM11:53am

That's a fantastic note

PM11:53am

From Prichard

BE11:53am

There was a weird story earlier in the week retreading the idea of Ashley buying back the 45% he doesn't own .....

11:53 am

BE11:54am

BE11:56am

Though, given Sports Direct isn't a really a listed company in any conventional or meningful way, it might not be a bad thing to see it head into private ownership for a bit. I'm not sure I'd want exposure via every tracker fund in the land to Ashley's inexplicable sportswear fiefdom.

11:56 am

PM12:01pm

How low is too low?
If a mainstream candidate emerges as a favourite from the first round of the French elections on Sunday as polls indicate (Figure 1), the market will need to adjust from current pricing. 1) Even relative to our own views (eg, we have been bullish US duration since December), global bond yields may have declined a bit too much a bit too fast, driven by 10y Bund yields at 24bp (vs our end-year forecast of 70bp). 2) Part of the risk premium in EUR/$ (estimated at 2 big figures in total) is likely to evaporate (by year-end we expect the EUR/$ to edge to 1.13). 3) European stocks continue to fare better than US stocks year-to-date and this may extend, particularly in rate-sensitive sectors. Any serious market discussion, however, will need to assess the short-term risks across the various election scenarios.

PM12:01pm

The downside scenario for risky assets…
Despite recent worries, the scenario least priced – which according to the latest polls isnot likely – isif Le Pen faces and beats Mélenchon in the second round. We recently ran a stress-testing exercise for the event of a Le Pen victory. We have allowed for a scenario where the Euro-area's backstops keep the shock localized and contained and another where the shock transforms into a global growth concern. Unsurprisingly, European assets get hit the most (e.g. European stocks decline up to 7.6% and the EUR TWI by up to 2.0% for every 100bps of widening in Euro-area peripheral spreads). The more surprising result is that one global asset remains very responsive across scenarios –10y Bund and UST yields decline by 15-20bps per 100bps of peripheral spread widening. The hit to S&P500, EM stocks, the dollar and credit remains cushioned until the point that global growth concerns spread out (Figure 5).

12:01 pm
PM12:01pm

… with a twist
Polls indicate that a Mélenchon victory is likely if he faces Le Pen in the second round. Similarly, if he faces Fillon (Figure 2). Although initially severe, the market implications of this outcome may be more short-lived than the Le Pen reaction. This is because Mélenchon would likely need to reach out to a more centrist audience ahead of the second round but also on the way to parliamentary elections in June.

PM12:01pm

he upside scenario for risky assets …
At the opposite extreme we consider a scenario where French tail outcomes disappear; i.e. one whereMacron faces Fillon in the second round. In this case, the additional 40-50bp spread between France and the periphery vs Germany declines (Figure 4). Using our sensitivities for a localized shock, this could boost EUR TWI by about 1pct (bringing EUR/$ closer to 1.09-1.10), UST and Bund yields by c. 8-10bp and the SX5E by up to 3%. Risky assets would benefit but to a smaller extent (Figure 3).

PM12:01pm

…and its limits
Crucially, even though Euro-area break-up concerns should dissipate thematically for a while, political risk will not disappear entirely for Euro-area assets; general elections in Italy are due by May 2018 at the latest. In addition, there are limits to spread tightening if the market starts factoring in the impact of a less dovish ECB (QE tapering).

What to do
The first-order market reaction should allow little room to position for the knee-jerk risk premium shift. Beyond the narrow election window, we see more downside in US 10y rates in a bad scenario and more upside in EUR/$ in a good scenario. Similarly, we believe weighted long France vs Italian sovereign bond spread trades hold a better risk/reward compared to Euro-area sovereign spreads vs Bunds, across most scenarios.
